item.title: Automation, AI, and the Future of Work: Insights from Economics
item.description:
This post is based on the chapter Artificial Intelligence, Automation, and Work [[1]] by Daron Acemoglu and Pascual Restrepo, from the Handbook The Economics of Artificial Intelligence. It also draws on related research by Acemoglu, Restrepo, and coauthors [[References]]. These works offer a framework for analyzing how automation affects labor markets using a task-based approach.

Channels of Automation’s Impact on labor demand

There are several key mechanisms through which automation influences labor demand, wages, and labor’s share in the economy. Importantly, the displacement effect stands out as the main negative force, while other mechanisms counterbalance it to varying degrees.
